1 Introduction

Previously, you have calculated the electric field due to a collection of point charges. From superposition, the electric field at any point in space is the sum of the electric field due to all point charges.

Suppose that you wanted to know the electric field created by a plastic rod that was positively charged by rubbing it against fabric. The number of charges that you would need to account for is on the order of > 1 0 20 \gt 10^{20} >1020. If you could do one calculation per second, computing the electric field due to each of the charges would take longer than the time since the Big Bang.

To allow for an answer in a finite amount of time, the approximation that charge is uniformly distributed along a line can be made. Consider 9 charges placed on a line as shown on the left-hand-side of the diagram below. To compute the electric field at the open circle, we would need to compute the electric field due to each of the 9 charges there. Graphically, we will make the approximation shown in the diagram. The 9 charges on the left are smeared out onto the line to form a continuous charge density.

\begin{center} \input{Continuous_Charge_Distributions/figures/Figure_2_1} \end{center}

Mathematically, the we are converting a sum to an integral. The electric field at the open circle is

E = k q 1 r ^ 1 r 1 2 + k q 2 r ^ 2 r 2 2 + â€¦ + k q N r ^ N r N 2 \begin{align*} \mathbf{E}=&kq_1\frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}_1}{r_1^2}+kq_2\frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}_2}{r_2^2}+â€¦+kq_N\frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}_N}{r_N^2} \end{align*} E=â€‹kq1â€‹r12â€‹r^1â€‹â€‹+kq2â€‹r22â€‹r^2â€‹â€‹+â€¦+kqNâ€‹rN2â€‹r^Nâ€‹â€‹â€‹

Using the notation of Griffiths, r \mathbf{r} r is the (single) position of the point of interest and r â€² \mathbf{r}' râ€² is the position of a charge, so

Ô‰ i = r âˆ’ r i â€² \textbf{\char"0509}_i=\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_i' Ô‰iâ€‹=râˆ’riâ€²â€‹

where this is

E = k q 1 Ô‰ ^ 1 Ô‰ 1 2 + k q 2 Ô‰ ^ 2 Ô‰ 2 2 + â€¦ + k q 9 Ô‰ ^ 9 Ô‰ N 2 = âˆ‘ i = 1 N k q i Ô‰ ^ i Ô‰ i 2 â‰ƒ âˆ« k d q Ô‰ ^ Ô‰ 2 \begin{align*} \mathbf{E}=& kq_1\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}_1}{\char"0509_1^2} +kq_2\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}_2}{\char"0509_2^2} +â€¦ +kq_9\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}_9}{\char"0509_N^2} \\ \\=&\sum_{i=1}^Nkq_i\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}_i}{\char"0509_i^2} \\ \\ \simeq & \int kdq\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{\char"0509^2} \end{align*} E==â‰ƒâ€‹kq1â€‹Ô‰12â€‹Ô‰^1â€‹â€‹+kq2â€‹Ô‰22â€‹Ô‰^2â€‹â€‹+â€¦+kq9â€‹Ô‰N2â€‹Ô‰^9â€‹â€‹i=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹kqiâ€‹Ô‰i2â€‹Ô‰^iâ€‹â€‹âˆ«kdqÔ‰2Ô‰^â€‹â€‹

where the integral approximation accuracy increases with N N N.

The arguments given above do not depend on the fact that the charges are on a line, and so the L \mathcal{L} L can be dropped. In addition, by convention, the approxmation symbol is replaced with an equality, giving

E = âˆ« k Ô‰ ^ Ô‰ 2 d q \boxed{\mathbf{E}=\int k\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{\char"0509^2}dq} E=âˆ«kÔ‰2Ô‰^â€‹dqâ€‹

The advantage of using the integral approximation is that to get an answer, we only need to solve an integral â€“ we do not need to compute electric field contribution for each point charge and then do a vector sum.

To emphasize the fact that the result of the integration depends on the unprimed variable r \mathbf{r} r, and that the result of integration should not have any primed variables, we sometimes write

E ( r ) = âˆ« k Ô‰ ^ Ô‰ 2 d q \mathbf{E}(\mathbf{r})=\int k\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{\char"0509^2}dq E(r)=âˆ«kÔ‰2Ô‰^â€‹dq

To simplify notation, we often write the integrand as

d E = k Ô‰ ^ Ô‰ 2 d q d\mathbf{E}=k\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{\char"0509^2}dq dE=kÔ‰2Ô‰^â€‹dq

which corresponds to the electric field due to a differential charge d q dq dq.

In the case where r \mathbf{r} r was written with cartesian coordinates, this would be

E ( x , y , z ) = âˆ« k Ô‰ ^ Ô‰ 2 d q \mathbf{E}(x,y,z)=\int k\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{\char"0509^2}dq E(x,y,z)=âˆ«kÔ‰2Ô‰^â€‹dq

2 Steps

Introductory physics textbooks often give examples on finding the electric field due to a continuous charge distribution for which there is a short-cut solution (especially for a ring or disk of charge). However, most continuous charge distribution problems do not have a short-cut solution. Griffiths gives only one example on computing the electric field using a general method.

In this section, I provide steps that can used to find the electric field for an arbitrary continuous charge distribution. Part of the method of solution shown here will be needed later when computing dipole approximations; the steps for computing the electric potential due to a continuous charge distribution and the magnetic field due to a current system will be similar (in the case of currents, the Biot-Savart equation is used instead of Coulombâ€™s Law).

2.1 Predicting Answer in Limits

Based on the problem statement and diagram, write down features that you expect your solution to have. For example,

  • For large z z z, solution should approach that for case where all charge on line/sheet, etc. is at the origin.

  • For small z z z, solution should approach that for an infinite line/sheet of charge, etc.

  • The computed electric field should be pointing is + x +x +x and + z +z +z direction or the computed electric field should have only a z z z-component.

Such statements will be used to check your final answer and also intermediate steps.

For example, in the case of a line of charge that extends from x = âˆ’ L x=-L x=âˆ’L to x = L x=L x=L,

  1. The electric field on the z z z-axis should only have a z z zâ€“component.

  2. For z â‰« L z\gg L zâ‰«L (far away from the line), one expects an answer that approaches the answer for a problem where all of the charges on the line are placed at the origin. In this case, the basic form of Coulombâ€™s Law for electric fields can be used to find the answer.

  3. For z â‰ª L z\ll L zâ‰ªL, one expects an answer that approaches the answer for an infinite line of charge (an ant placed near the origin will conclude that the charges extend to infinity in both directions). In this case, one can look up the equation for the electric field due to an infinite line of charge (or use Gaussâ€™ Law to find it).

2.2 Finding d l dl dl, d a da da, or d Ï„ d\tau dÏ„

The differential charge d q dq dq must be written in terms of a coordinate system.

  • For charges on a line, d q = Î» d l dq=\lambda dl dq=Î»dl

  • For charges on a surface, d q = Ïƒ d a dq=\sigma da dq=Ïƒda

  • For charges in a volume, d q = Ï d Ï„ dq=\rho d\tau dq=ÏdÏ„

In this step, d l dl dl, d a da da, or d Ï„ d\tau dÏ„ is written in terms of a coordinate system (usually cartesian, cylindrical, or spherical). The choice of coordinate system depends on the problem; usually, the coordinate system that is â€œbestâ€ will be somewhat obvious (â€œbestâ€ is used in the sense that it makes the math easiest).

Note that when writen with a coordinate variable (e.g., d x â€² dx' dxâ€² instead of a generic variable (e.g., d l dl dl), the differential element is written with a prime. The reason is that the position of the charges that cause the electric field is by convention written with a prime and we want to integrate over the position of the charges. Ideally, we would use d q â€² dq' dqâ€², d l â€² dl' dlâ€², d Ïƒ â€² d\sigma' dÏƒâ€², and d Ï„ â€² d\tau' dÏ„â€² to emphasize this, but this is not the convention.

2.2.1 Example â€“ Constant Line of Charge

For a line of charge with charge density Î» \lambda Î» over âˆ’ L â‰¤ x â‰¤ L -L\le x\le L âˆ’Lâ‰¤xâ‰¤L, find d q dq dq.

Answer

If the differential charges lie on the x x xâ€“axis, then d l = d x â€² dl = dx' dl=dxâ€². So the electric field due to d q dq dq can now be written by replacing d q dq dq with Î» d x â€² \lambda dx' Î»dxâ€². If Î» \lambda Î» depends on x â€² x' xâ€², we should write d q = Î» ( x â€² ) d x â€² dq=\lambda(x')dx' dq=Î»(xâ€²)dxâ€² to emphasize the fact that the charge on a differential element depends on its position.

To check d E d\mathbf{E} dE, plug in a few values of ( x â€² , y â€² , z â€² ) (x',y',z') (xâ€²,yâ€²,zâ€²) and verify that it is consistent the expected result.

2.5 Simplifying d E d\mathbf{E} dE using Symmetry Arguments

The most frequent type of symmetry will be cancelation symmetry, where pairs of differential charges create an electric field at a point with a component that cancels.

2.5.1 Example â€“ Constant Î» \lambda Î»

For a line of charge with constant charge density Î» \lambda Î» over âˆ’ L â‰¤ x â‰¤ L -L\le x\le L âˆ’Lâ‰¤xâ‰¤L and for a point on the y y yâ€“axis,

From this, we conclude that the horizontal component of the E \mathbf{E} E will end up to be zero after integration.

A mathematical way of showing this is to note that d E x ( x â€² ) = âˆ’ d E x ( âˆ’ x â€² ) dE_x(x')=-dE_x(-x') dExâ€‹(xâ€²)=âˆ’dExâ€‹(âˆ’xâ€²) and so summation of d E x dE_x dExâ€‹ over Â± L \pm L Â±L will result in exact cancellation of d E x dE_x dExâ€‹.

2.6 Integrating d E d\mathbf{E} dE

There are two possibilities:

  1. The integral can be solved â€œexactlyâ€, which informally means standard methods can be used to do the integration, e.g., using trig substitutions, an integral table, or entering the integral into Mathematica or WolframAlpha. The technical term is a â€œclosed-formâ€ solution. An example of an integral with a closed-form solution is âˆ« 0 Ï€ sin â¡ ( k u ) d u = ( cos â¡ ( k Ï€ ) âˆ’ 1 ) / k \int_0^{\pi} \sin (ku) du = (\cos (k\pi) - 1)/k âˆ«0Ï€â€‹sin(ku)du=(cos(kÏ€)âˆ’1)/k.

  2. The solution of the integral is an infinite series. An example is the elliptic integral of the first kind:

    âˆ« 0 Ï€ / 2 d u / 1 + k 2 sin â¡ 2 u = ( Ï€ / 2 ) ( 1 + k 2 ( 1 / 2 ) 2 + k 4 ( ( 1 â‹… 2 ) / ( 3 â‹… 4 ) ) 2 + â€¦ ) \int_0^{\pi/2}du/\sqrt{1+k^2\sin^2u}=(\pi/2)\big(1+k^2(1/2)^2+k^4((1\cdot 2)/(3\cdot 4))^2+â€¦\big) âˆ«0Ï€/2â€‹du/1+k2sin2uâ€‹=(Ï€/2)(1+k2(1/2)2+k4((1â‹…2)/(3â‹…4))2+â€¦).

    We will actually encounter such integrals later in the semester - they also appear in classical mechanics.

    In these cases, one must convert the integrand to a polynomial using a Taylor Series expansion. This will be covered in detail later in the semester when electric and magnetic dipoles are covered. The basic procedure is to re-write the integrand as an infinite series, e.g.,

    âˆ« f ( x â€² ) d x â€² = âˆ« ( c 0 + c 1 x â€² + c 2 x â€² 2 + â€¦ ) d x â€² \int f(x')dx' = \int \big(c_0 + c_1x' + c_2x'^2 + â€¦\big)dx' âˆ«f(xâ€²)dxâ€²=âˆ«(c0â€‹+c1â€‹xâ€²+c2â€‹xâ€²2+â€¦)dxâ€²

    where the constants c 0 , c 1 , c 2 , â€¦ c_0, c_1, c_2, â€¦ c0â€‹,c1â€‹,c2â€‹,â€¦ are determined using the Taylor Series expansion formula. Written in this way, the integral only involves the integration of polynomials. There are subtleties to this method â€“ one needs to ensure that the series is converging and sometimes several approximations to f ( x â€² ) f(x') f(xâ€²) are needed, one for locations near the charge distribution and one at far locations.

2.6.1 Example â€“ Integral can be solved exactly

Integrate d E d\mathbf{E} dE found in Example 2.2.1.

First, we need to write d q dq dq in terms of a differential length element. In general, d q = Î» d l dq=\lambda dl dq=Î»dl. In this problem, the differential length is the width of d q dq dq, which is along the x x x direction, so d l = d x dl=dx dl=dx and d q = Î» d x dq = \lambda dx dq=Î»dx. The equation of the electric field created by a single differential charge at an arbitrary location on the x x x-axis found previously was

d E = k Î» d x ( x 2 + y o 2 ) 3 / 2 ( âˆ’ x Ä± ^ + y o È· ^ ) d\mathbf{E} = k\frac{\lambda dx}{(x^2 + y_o^2)^{3/2}}(-x\boldsymbol{\hat{\imath}} + y_o\boldsymbol{\hat{\jmath}}) dE=k(x2+yo2â€‹)3/2Î»dxâ€‹(âˆ’xî„±^+yoâ€‹îˆ·^â€‹)

Before you attempt to do an integration, you should find ways to avoid doing integration. Based on the diagram, for every charge with x < 0 x<0 x<0, there is a charge with x > 0 x>0 x>0 that cancels its horizontal electric field. (Look back at the previous tutorial where this fact was also used.)

As a result, we know that the answer cannot have a x x x component and the first integral must evaluate to zero. Mathematically, another way to show this is to use the fact that the integrand of the first integral, âˆ’ x / ( x 2 + y o 2 ) 3 / 2 -x/(x^2+y_o^2)^{3/2} âˆ’x/(x2+yo2â€‹)3/2 is an odd function on the interval x = [ âˆ’ a , a ] x=[-a,a] x=[âˆ’a,a].

E = âˆ« âˆ’ a a k Î» y o , d x ( x 2 + y o 2 ) 3 / 2 È· ^ \mathbf{E} = \int_{-a}^{a}k\lambda\frac{ y_o,dx}{(x^2 + y_o^2)^{3/2}}\boldsymbol{\hat{\jmath}} E=âˆ«âˆ’aaâ€‹kÎ»(x2+yo2â€‹)3/2yoâ€‹,dxâ€‹îˆ·^â€‹

On exams, you will only be asked to set up the integral and it will be assumed that you can either do the integral or look it up. For the curious, the integration is given here.

The integral part of the right-hand-side is E y E_y Eyâ€‹

E y = âˆ« âˆ’ a a k Î» y o , d x ( x 2 + y o 2 ) 3 / 2 E_y = \int_{-a}^{a}k\lambda\frac{y_o,dx}{(x^2 + y_o^2)^{3/2}} Eyâ€‹=âˆ«âˆ’aaâ€‹kÎ»(x2+yo2â€‹)3/2yoâ€‹,dxâ€‹

This integral was given in Example 21.10 of the textbook (but with different variables). Using it gives

Some students used this equation with z z z instead of s s s.

To get an exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system of the problem, one needs to write s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ and s s s in terms of parameters and the coordinate system given in the problem of x x x, z z z, and m m m: s = âˆ’ z ( âˆ’ x ^ + z ^ / m ) \mathbf{s}=-z(-\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\hat{\mathbf{z}}/m) s=âˆ’z(âˆ’x^+z^/m). I gave full credit if it was recognized that at z â‰ª a z\ll a zâ‰ªa, the field should be perpendicular to the line. Some students said the field would be zero because these points are on the line - this is not correct - z â‰ª a z\ll a zâ‰ªa means just above the infinitely thin line; only z = 0 z = 0 z=0 would be exactly on the line.

3.6 Line of Charge with Parabolic Shape

A line of charge with a charge density of Î» \lambda Î» has a parabolic shape of z = x 2 z=x^2 z=x2 and extends from x = âˆ’ a x=-a x=âˆ’a to x = a x=a x=a.

For z > 0 z>0 z>0, expect E \mathbf{E} E to be in âˆ’ z ^ -\hat{\mathbf{z}} âˆ’z^ direction. The on the z-axis, the electric field has no component in the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ direction because a charge at position x = x o x=x_o x=xoâ€‹ produces an electric field with a component in the âˆ’ x ^ -\hat{\mathbf{x}} âˆ’x^ direction that is canceled by that from a charge at x = âˆ’ x o x=-x_o x=âˆ’xoâ€‹. The integration requires writing d l dl dl and the limits of integration in terms of a coordinate system.

The general formula for a differential element in cartesian coordinates is

which has a magnitude

3.8 Ring of Charge

Write your answer on a blank sheet of paper of printer paper.

A ring of charge with charge density of Î» \lambda Î» has a radius a a a, is centered at the origin, and lies in the x âˆ’ y x-y xâˆ’y plane.

  1. When z < < a z<<a z<<a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E (magnitude and direction) on the z z z-axis, and why*?

  2. When z > > a z>>a z>>a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E (magnitude and direction) on the z z z-axis, and why*?

  3. Find V V V on the z z z-axis (that is, find V ( z ) V(z) V(z)).

  4. Find E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis (that is, find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z)).

*That is, without doing any integration, what do you expect the answer to be like in these limits. I gave many examples of this in class.

All final equations should be expressed in terms of k k k or Ïµ 0 , Î» \epsilon_0,\lambda Ïµ0â€‹,Î», and a a a using any coordinate system.

[[Image:ring_of_charge.png|400px]]

Answer

1. Expect E = 0 \mathbf{E}=0 E=0 at the origin. One can find a d q dq dq on one side of the ring that has a d q dq dq on the other side of the ring that produces an electric field equal in magnitude and opposite in direction at the origin. A tiny distance above the origin, the electric field lines are nearly horizontal, so the z z z component should be nearly zero. 3. There are three general ways to do this:
